body:
I just came across this also testing our app against the 2.0 sample model repository in the TextureTransformTest. Would be good to at least store the properties. I guess they would need to be stored as material properties related to textures similar to the wrapping modes?

Had a quick look at what might be involved in implementing it and since most of the extension detection stuff is there it looks like first the properties would need to be added to the glTF2Asset and then converted into material properties by flattening the offset, rotation and scale into something storable in the existing AI_MATKEY_UVTRANSFORM_BASE key.

I wouldn't like to get too far into it before hearing from someone if this might be the right approach.
Anyone else interested in this feature?
Just posted it on twitter to get more feedback.
Sounds like a good feature to support IMO
@kimkulling I am indeed interested in this feature.
I also believe this extension is a very important one, with many glTF applications supporting it already.

@kimkulling I'm interested as well. 

It seems `AI_MATKEY_UVTRANSFORM_BASE` is unused in the glTF2 loader. Is it possible to put the combined UV matrix in there?
I am currently working on this feature

Excellent! Just a heads up, I imagine it will be tricky to test this feature until issue #2718 is also addressed since the underlying UVs won't be correct. I'm not sure if people are reproducing that issue as no one else commented on it yet.
Unfortuantely there was a small issue with this. The y translation was taking its value from the X translation. I will submit a pull request with a change to fix that.

issue.title: Migenius fix doubleexport

repository.name: assimp
repository.description: The official Open-Asset-Importer-Library Repository. Loads 40+ 3D-file-formats into one unified and clean data structure.

issue.body:
Remove duplicate call to the exporter function in the Exporter base class. This fixes issue #2718 though it is not clear why, the organisation of pre-processing steps, verbose scenes and other factors and the fact that the scene is duplicated during export seem to affect this.

This should ideally be merged prior to the release of 5.0.1 since basically from what I can tell this means the full export is being called twice, for large files that would significantly increase export time and as the linked issue shows, created at least one unforseen issue. It was hard to track down.

I don't believe this was intentional, the line prior to the offending line was indented differently and it wasn't clear until the indentation was unified that the issue was there. It was introduced by commit 3d0775eebc0f2a86b87752385782e9b90c83279f and the commit messages by @ywangsc did not mention a need to export twice so I assume it was an error.

body: Have been doing further testing and unfortunately the rotation values are not coming through. I haven't been able to determine why yet and will need to continue investigating. The code looks right, I tried some different ways to do the same thing but they don't make any difference.

I haven't identified the rotation issue yet, however just to note for glTF the UV rotation is around the origin, which in glTF is the top left of the texture, where as Assimp documents the mRotation member of aiUVTransform as being around 0.5,0.5 (center of the image). As a result it may not be possible to represent as a strict TRS when combined. Further investigation needed.

Ok, so the commit referenced above addresses the issue with rotations not being retrieved when using aiGetMaterialUVTransform (and just Get() on the material itself since that calls that). Previously it was only possible to obtain the rotation by manually calling aiGetMaterialFloatArray.

The issue mentioned where rotation origins differ above still remains and I think is the last item that would need to be addressed.

So the issue is actually a little more complex. Basically the coordinate system for each of the transformation values is different between glTF and Assimp. Here are the origins (at least I assume Assimp uses 0,0 at the bottom left of textures) in the Assimp space.

| Component   | glTF Origin | Assimp Origin |
| ------------| ----------- | ------------- |
| Translation | 0,1         | 0,0           |
| Scale       | 0,1         | 0,0           |
| Rotation    | 0,1         | 0.5,0.5       |

I suspect the easiest way to handle this will be to deal with them as matrices then decompose them back to the translation rotation scale components afterwards. This is going to be a bit more involved than hoped.

Have now implemented the change of coordinates needed and will do a PR. Results now match the glTF 2.0 test case [here](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF-Sample-Models/tree/master/2.0/TextureTransformTest). Quick rendering from our software.

![KHR_texture_transform](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5742686/69682583-f6b83f00-1105-11ea-905b-58160ac24172.jpg)

Hopefully this now makes a complete implementation for this extension.

issue.title: Migenius fix khrtexturetransform

repository.name: assimp
repository.description: The official Open-Asset-Importer-Library Repository. Loads 40+ 3D-file-formats into one unified and clean data structure.

issue.body: Adding the needed change of coordinates for KHR_texture_transform. This should hopefully complete issue #2119 now.
